REVIEW_TITLE: Very impressive architectural exhibitions and models.
REVIEW_BODY: Every Architect and citizen interested in urban development must visit the gallery. There is lot more to learn from it. If you have a big group, engage a tour guide - they're really knowledgeable and helpful!
Great models of the city and Information on the developement plan for Singapore in the future! And absolutely free! Really worth a visit especially during a short rain period.
The gallery was very captivating. I got to see how they slowly build Singapore. The gallery was also very interactive. I liked the scale model alot.

REVIEW_TITLE: Return for the Cherry Blossom season
REVIEW_BODY: was there on late March ... was too late to visit as some of the cherry blossom flowers were dying ... but other flowers were still in good & pretty conditions especially the orchids...

REVIEW_TITLE: If you don't have much time...
REVIEW_BODY: Overall birdseye view of sg. Future planning and landscape. First stop here to get overall view. Give Sentosa a miss, Go to east coast instead.

We were taken here by a proud Singaporean local who wanted to show us a birds eye perspective of his city. We were not disappointed...the planning, history and cultural preservation were at the forefront. If you have a few hours, go and have a look. We have been coming to Singas for years, and this was well worth the visit!

The Gallery is currently undergoing renovations and will take up to a year. You can still visit level 1 where the model of the Singapore city is located. However the other parts in level 1 and 2 closed. Was a disappointing trip for today but hope to be back again end next year.

REVIEW_TITLE: Pop in for a birds-eye view of the island and the city
REVIEW_BODY: Terrific models of the island and of the city that give you a great overview. There's lots of information for those interested in urban planning but we just popped in for the models (and the air-conditioning!). They really are great models! And it's very close to the Maxwell hawker centre (lunch).
Visited the Maxwell food center and walked in to this building by chance and saw the map. It was great to learn about the development around the area.
this place tells about the history of Singapore and how the city was built, good place to visit for traveller
The gardens are so beautifully presented. Each section has a theme and the amount of thought and effort that is displayed is obvious and in places very entertaining. Well worth a visit.
We visited Singapore with our children, there were enjoy and full experience. We have visited a few place and we plan to visit again in future

REVIEW_TITLE: A perfect idea about what is Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: You can see the evolution of Singapore and the Maser plan of the country. It is easy to visit also for children and very interesting.

If you are intersted in the way how Singapore was build to the modern city and ceneter of business you need to visit the exposition there. It will show you the way of thinking and planning the city grow for the people and good life there. Very interesting. Entry is free.
The model of the city is great, and there are some brilliant historic photos and descriptions of how the city has been developed.

Would recommend this place to all newcomers to Singapore as the detailed scale model on the ground floor gives a great overview about the various parts and neighbourhoods of Singapore and a sense of where these are located vis a vis the CBD and nature reserves. Also interesting for people who have lived in Singapore for a while and know the various iconic buildings and developments for which construction drawings are shown.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting for the whole family, insightful and impressive
REVIEW_BODY: We spent 70min with a family of four and would have stayed longer, if it was not closing by 5pm. It really grabbed the attention of everyone. When other countries will start running out of land in 50 years they will look to Singapore, because the Singaporeans already have invented everything that is needed to run a city sustainably on limited space. Very impressive. Learned more about urban planning than in any other city before.

A compulsory visit for any people discovering Singapore for the first time ! It shows you the evolution of the city, its development, its urbanism. A lot of interactive activities for the kids who always enjoy that place.

REVIEW_TITLE: A Very Useful Information of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: This gallery is located near the Tanjong Pagar MRT Station. At this place, you can learn a lot of things related to the development history of Singapore and their upcoming plannings about the city. I can say that this is the most informative gallery that I’ve ever visited in the context of urban topics. Very recommended, and don’t forget to stop by at the interactive games upstairs.
Thoroughly enjoyed having a wander around and reading all the information. Well set out. The miniature display of Singapore was really well down and would have taken a lot of time to build.

This gallery provides tourists and educationalists a perfect big picture of the city, from what it is today and its envisaged future. A brief history of SG's development is shown here, and how its forefathers turned the once brackish, swampy small island into the first world status it is today. It recounts the 50 years of SGs land management and zoning plan to make the city one of the most livable in the world. All free.

As a geographer I totally loved this place - it was on my must visit list, and I wasn't disappointed. I loved the scaled 3-D models/maps of Singapore. Very interesting images and stories about the geographical changes which have occurred on the island of Singapore over the years. It provides you with a good understanding of the complex issues related in designing and developing a city like Singapore.
There were great interactives as well for people to play and explore

This is a lovely, free museum to learn more about the history of Singapore. From extremely detailed models of the country to exhibits about Singapore infrastructure, this museum offers a whole host of knowledge about the country. I really enjoyed learning about the country's development.

REVIEW_TITLE: A hidden gem and a must if you want to understand this island nation
REVIEW_BODY:
I honestly would not have thought to visit this gallery, but it was part of a walking tour (Food Tours Singapore), and a testament to the understated relevance of development to the culture of Singapore.

The gallery is free admission, and gives you real insight into the size of Singapore in comparison to other large cities, it's real need for constant re-evaluation of development to keep up with it's growing population, and a history of it's redevelopment and the significance of different cultures on the construction and urban planning from the days as a port city to today.

A great way to spend an hour if you're in the Chinatown area and need a cool airconditioned reprieve from the humidity, close to hawker centres for a treat afterwards! and even great for kids of all ages

My daughter made me go to the URA centre, as I had previously lived in Singapore in the 80's - this display is amazing. It shows the quality of the Singapore people to have a display of a plan for their future.

Go if you want to know how Singapore is built and made. Decade by decade they have shown their growth. It is really amazing to see how they have grown in past 50 years. They have laid down master-plans for the future and its amazing how they are chasing these plans.

REVIEW_TITLE: The Future and Past of Singapore City
REVIEW_BODY: We were pleasantly surprised by our visit here! We loved learning about both the past and the future plans for Singapore and we learnt alot about the city itself. Highly interactive and a great place to take the family as there is something for everyone, we love the large scale model of the city itself.

REVIEW_TITLE: A must-see though it is low on tripadvisor things to do
REVIEW_BODY: To understand how Singapore became this beautiful, eco friendly and an amazing country you need to check this museum out. They explain how much of planning goes into making their roads, structures, underground, transport and greenery, The entire city's 3D miniature model is in one floor of the building. Quite a feat to replicate the whole of Singapore with all its sky scrapers and every street. Its a free for all and yet it is not in the top 10 list .I almost missed this attraction in Singapore, managed to do it on the last that too an hour before closing. You will even see a Malay lady doing the next new building's miniature.
Good information on the development and plans for the City of Singapore. It is interesting with outstanding displays. Plus it is totally FREE.
They are so forward thinking in Singapore. Display gives you great overlay of city. It is such a small country but they are so innovative on planning
staff at registration counter were very friendly. i like the interactive exhibitions, as well as the hourly shows. there's a game where you can plan a city with fellow gallery visitors!

The tour took us to the gallery and looking at the display of the city was great and the info from the tour guide was very interesting. To see the city in this was was great and to see what is plan intresting

REVIEW_TITLE: Fascinating insights to how the city was planned and built
REVIEW_BODY: Fans of the game SimCity will love this exhibition on how Singapore was built and what the plans are for the future. Interactive, informative. Excellent.

REVIEW_TITLE: A wonderful look at Singapore's planning
REVIEW_BODY:
I'd intended to visit this Gallery but could never find the time to do it.

The school holidays gave us the perfect chance.

Entry is free and there are wonderful scale models of Singapore and it's different areas.

It was great to see literally a bird's eye view of the development and how well planned it has all been.

There are nuggets of information about the development as well as key architectural highlights of some of the buildings.

A nice way to spend an hour.

The main exhibit is a model of the whole island with future planning. It is fascinating. In addition the exhibition shows maps of Singapore along history. I was amazed to see the 1971 plan for Singapore. For almost 50 years this plan is realized step by step. Really remarkable. I enjoyed the visit very much!

REVIEW_TITLE: More great Singapore architecture, and fabulous art
REVIEW_BODY: This beautifully designed building which marries the old Supreme Court building and the old City Hall is a treasure. There are exhibitions and activities for children and adults. We loved the large exhibition of Singapore art from early days to contemporary.
A place to find out the art and pictures of Singapore and surrounds. Helpful staff and will guide you around

Located between historic Chinatown and the Central Business District, Singapore City Gallery is a three storey visitor centre which houses an enormous model replica, giving visitors a complete view of the Central Area of Singapore. It also shows the city's physical transformation past, present and future. Opening time is in attached photo.

If you like maps and urban planning GO HERE! Fascinating. Loved the 1:400 scale model, I could get lost looking at it for hours. Knowledgeable volunteers offer free tours and extra tidbits throughout the day.
1 point off since parts of the museum were roped off.
We stumbled upon this by accident. Very interesting and informative on the growth and development of the city.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting scale model of the city state
REVIEW_BODY: The scale model of the city was quite intricate and interesting. Even though it is not a must see, if you are in the vicinity of Maxwell Food Centre, it is well worth the effort to pop in for a quick look especially since it is free.

To be able to see how the planning of this Island nation has and is taking place is amazing. It was great to see the way the city is being shaped and shaping a social structure that at least on the surface is healthy.
Nothing beats a free gallery. The Singapore City Gallery shows you how Singapore has been developed over the years and gives you glimpses into the future.
A great place to step into out of the afternoon humidity to get a feel for the history of Singapore. A big 3d map shows the layout of the city as well as future plans for reclaiming land.

A must-see for people interested in how Singapore was planned and built. It gives plenty of information about this amazing city state - history , planning , infrastructure and future development opportunities.

REVIEW_TITLE: Excellent Introduction to Singapore in the heart of Chinatown
REVIEW_BODY: This is a free city planning museum next to the Maxwell Center Food Stalls and is an excellent Introduction to Singapore in the heart of Chinatown. There are floor sized 3D model exhibits of the entire city that are very impressive. There is an excellent discussion of the different types of architecture found in the city as well as the thought behind the sustainability planning of the area. Well worth a visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting gallery and plan of city
REVIEW_BODY: Not somewhere we would have thought to come without our guide, but glad we did as the exhibit on the history of the country and the scale models of the city and expansion plans were fascinating and gave a lot of cultural context to our short stop in Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: Best thing we did in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: We started our visit to Singapore here. In terms of community planning, perspective and history, this place gives a really good base to start exploring the city. In a short time, we were introduced to the culture and development of Singapore. We were amazed at the smart planning and development. Singapore is an amazing place and this Gallery exhibit will help you understand why.

REVIEW_TITLE: Not to be missed if you have any interest in this unique city-state
REVIEW_BODY:
Singapore is has a very interesting history and mixture of cultures and there are several excellent museums to learn about it's people, past and present.

But Singapore is unique in it's rapid development in just a few decades from what was essentially a colonial backwater to a high-tech global city-state tasked with providing for over 5 million residents on a finite island that struggles with its size.

The City Gallery's exhibits highlight the building and infrastructure challenges faced and how each challenge has been (and continues to be) met, from reclaimed land to transportation to housing to the creation of whole neighborhoods, water resources and management, and the preservation of its historical districts and shop houses. The enormous 3-D scale model of Singapore is worth the prices of admission, but there is so much more. It is a great place to start to learn about how this place came to be what it is and get a feel for the physicality of the city.

As in everything Singapore, the City Museum is well organized, quiet, with good lighting and clean restrooms. You could go through this museum in an hour or you could easily spent 2 or 3, depending on your interest and time constraints.
This place is great. Tells you all the changes from the old to the new and the future for Singapore. It's very interesting and interactive in places. Would recommend.
This is the place to go to get an idea of the way Singapore thinks and plans. You can see all the work that goes into making a city of this size work so smoothly. The models are unbelievable.

This is a bit out of the way and possibly not my first choice of sights to see. How wrong I was. To fully understand how Singapore has been so precisely planned and developed over the decades you need to see this place. When you look at the Singapore skyline and sights you may believe that these were just randomly built in a race to build the biggest, wierdest buildings alongside each other. But after visiting you will understand how much planning took place, especially the reclaimation of land from the sea.
In my view a must see and free!

REVIEW_TITLE: Great spot to learn about singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore is quite a well planned city, and only when you know what went into it can you truly appreciate it. Do here to know all that and see a large model of the downtown area.

REVIEW_TITLE: Would have never of thought to visit here
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited here on our Chinatown walking tour and were really surprised when we went inside.

The have a scale model of all of Singapore showing current and future developments.

There is also a informative display about the development of Singapore upstairs.

If you are in the area spend 30 minutes of so and have a look around. We found it very interesting.

Worth a look if you're interested in city planning or learning about how Singapore physically transformed itself in recent decades. The city replicas look impressive. The staff and volunteers at the gallery seemed quite happy to explain this aspect of Singapore's story to visitors.

We spent a few hours wandering freely around this modern gallery which explains in innovative ways, how Singapore has grown, matured and developed over the years. There are a variety of benches inside the reception area and are made from the old National Stadium seats. They were apparently part of a local competition and the results are incredibly inventive and quirky, and they aren't even in the exhibition space, they're just dotted around for visitors to enjoy. The water feature in the reception area is wonderful, and apparently catches a few people out, who mistake the expansive marble covered flowing water for a seating area....take a change of clothes!
Inside the gallery, which is free to enter, is a very interesting pictorial history of this beautiful island state and how innovation and sensitive planning have taken this once Colonial outpost from poverty into a vibrant, productive, verdant, modern and pristine country. The huge scaled down cityscape model is amazingly lifelike and fully shows the vast improvements that are being and have been made over recent decades. This might be seen as a rainy day activity, however it warrants a visit whatever the weather, and greatly enhanced our understanding of this beautiful island and its people. Give it a try, it will be a delightful couple of hours, well spent.

REVIEW_TITLE: Think Singapore know where their going. Your right, they do.
REVIEW_BODY:
This exhibition shows what a clever planning government this is.

Singapore has a plan for their city state, unlike my home town. They know where the need is, they plan to address it and they are successful.

Well worth a couple of hours in this place to see some of the history and their view of the future.

It's free and it well air conditioned.
A beautiful air conditioned building with excellent wifi and toilets. Ground floor foyer has an excellent, very large 3D model of the whole island of Singapore which makes an excellent spectacle

I enjoyed my short visit to the Singapore City Gallery. It gave me an insight into the history of Singapore as well as its future plans. The 3D model of Singapore was very nicely constructed and detailed. A must visit for tourists and locals alike.

Had not heard of this gallery, but was recommend to us.

We had a great time earning about how Singapore was planned and where the town planner are taking the country over the next 20+ years. The model of Singapore on the ground floor is fantastic.

Learnt so much about Singapore at this free exhibition! It's close to Chinatown and perfect for a hot humid afternoon. There were so many facts that I didn't know about. The exhibitions were clear and easy to understand. There were some school kids with their teachers but it didn't create too much fuss.

Stumbled upon this free gallery while exploring Chinatown/Ann Siang Hill. This is for the architectural buffs and they have a 'to scale' map of the whole Singapore including new and upcoming developments. Well, that's because this is the Urban Renewal Authority's gallery, no one else does it better than them. You can basically see the future of Singapore through the eyes of this Ministry. And heck it's FREE!

Do check out their glass lift!
You need to visit this location to understand and see how singapore is changing in the future, the gallery is free to visit.
definitely worth a stop really helps with understanding both the colonial history of Singapore as well as its post-colonial transformation and where it is likely going. paradise for planners!
A great insight into Singapore's development. Really informative and interesting. The city models are fantastic. Really worth a trip - and it's free!

REVIEW_TITLE: The Best Way to learn facts of the City
REVIEW_BODY: Huge model of Singapore. There a so many things to do and create by your own. Example: You have the part to create your "own" Singapore. In a virutual mode you get a piece of land and you must build schools, house, transportation system like in the real city. Great fun and the admission is free.

REVIEW_TITLE: Perfect way to start your visit!
REVIEW_BODY: The gallery has a scaled diorama of the entire city. Makes it easier to understand the areas of the city and the different buildings.

My wife and I visited this gallery for a self-guided tour while on route to Chinatown. It provides great insight into all the planning that's gone into the city, both above and below ground. It really is amazing how organized the city is and how much thought is put into green space, the environment, transportation, culture, economic development, etc... For instance, they have layers of infrastructure underground, up to 150 meters, and use the rock they dig out to further expand the city above ground. I advise seeing this gallery early in your trip so you've an appreciation for the city as you tour it.

A fantastic way to get an overview of Singapore both geographically and historically.
As a free entry attraction in a government building, this one may be easy to overlook but there are plenty of interactive displays and the models are amazing. Highly recommended.
Make sure to make your way upstairs, the other model is even more impressive than the one in the foyer and there's lots more to see.

REVIEW_TITLE: Answered all of my Singapore questions
REVIEW_BODY: Terrific topographical map, historic information and video displays help a newcomer understand how Singapore grew from a small fishing village into the metropolis it is today. Additionally, plans for,the future are shared. Very visually interesting.

If you are at all interested in urban planning, you have to go to this gallery. It’s free and really well put together. On the first floor you can see a scale model of the city, but upstairs is where you get to understand how Singapore came to be what it is. I’d go back for a second visit if I had time.

Anna Ong our fantastic tour guide took us here, worth the visit for the 50 year plan model alone,so much detail and what a fantastic idea. It is so good you can pick out all the landmarks and hotels and great place to walk around, not much of a detour either.

REVIEW_TITLE: Gives a good perspective on Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Whenever I tour friends around Singapore, I always make sure this little museum in the CBD is one of the first stop. It primarily tells how Singapore was planned and gives a good introduction to life in the Little Red Dot. From how Singapore gets its water, to how it disposes of its waste, how its communities are planned and the types of housing that has evolved over the years, this little gallery showcases all these.

REVIEW_TITLE: Fascinating for anyone thrilled by this city.
REVIEW_BODY: Not many tourists know about this place. The URA building is very near to the bottom end of China town and quite easily accessible. The Building itself is a government ministry building, but the bottom three floors are open to the public. The key thing here to see - and its completely free - is the huge scale models of Singapore city with immaculate detail. See how the country has reclaimed 1/3 of it's landmass from the sea in the last 30 years and discover how much of the CBD, Marina Bay Sands and even Changi airport were underwater not 50 years ago. A really fascinating insight into how this city was built.

Be sure to visit all levels of this gallery. Its totally free and has many different interactive displays and exhibits. You can learn all about resource management, land use and the plan for Singapore going forward. Great place. Must see in Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: An overview of the well planned country
REVIEW_BODY: Seriously, many display of such nature are usually academic. Not here. They had summarized their achievements into a single exhibit. Great show off to our overseas guest. Adjourn to the Maxwell Road market for a cuppa of coffee & kaya toast later.
Well worth a visit, it outlines the urbane development of Singapore over the past 50 years and the future plans using graphics, displays and models.

REVIEW_TITLE: One place to see the whole Singapore tranfrom from the old age to the mordern city
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a free exhibition for tourist and local to visit to see how this city develop to a garden city.
Visitors can see the develop master plan of every corner of Singapore, and also some model of the building in Singapore, also there are some touch screen monitor for you to play along the develop plan, there are some corner to show how deep the development goes and how the drain system work too.

We had seen the good reviews for this so on our last day here decided to go have a look. We took a long way there. However finally found it with help of some locals. We were tired so only explored the bottom floor..what we saw very impressive. Great for design students , town planning students or those into architecture or just the tourist interested in how Singapore has evolved.

This is on Maxwell Road, close to the Maxwell Road hawker centre in Chinatown. Not only will you learn a lot about the history of the island through displays and audio visual presentations but the scale model of the city centre is a phenomenal sight.

REVIEW_TITLE: Very interesting, especially if you are interested in town planning
REVIEW_BODY: Very detailed and interesting display with large models, don't miss if you are interested in the development history of Singapore and planning and development of towns.
You get a great prospective of Singapore, being able to see the complete layout of the city and read/hear about it was great.
A really interesting insight into future planning for Singapore. Lots of models to show lay out of the whole island and the city.
You not only see the history of Singapore, but the future of Singapore. The government here plans out 40 to 50 years and it shows in what's been done and what's going to be done.

REVIEW_TITLE: best kept secret for urban buffs
REVIEW_BODY: it is a really experience to visit the gallery with its giant model of Singapore landscape, the presenat and the next 30 years to come. A great tribute picture gallery to show the old Singapore and its iconic building. A must visit for architect buff.

The Singapore City Gallery is an excellent place to learn about how Singapore has developed from a fishing village into one of the most successful countries in SE Asia. The vision of the city-planners and the remarkable land reclamation programme has ensured Singapore's success. An added bonus is that it is free!!!

REVIEW_TITLE: Urban Redevelopment Authority model for future Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Our local guide, who was once an intern for the Urban Redevelopment Authority, brought us here to show us the models of the future Singapore and the displays about the history of Singapore. If you are impressed with what the city looks like now, you should definitely stop by to see these exhibits. It explains how most of what we currently see has been done in the past 50 years, with the bulk of it in the past 20 years. It shows where they plan to continue building. And when Singapore makes plans, things happen. It is very impressive, unless you factor in the people who are forced to move. Their say is exercised when they vote, and they have voted for the same party for those same 50 years, so I would have to say that in general they are satisfied with the direction of the country. Trying to implement anything like this in another democracy would be nearly impossible. Lots to think about, and these exhibits show all the thought that went into Singapore's progress and is going into Singapore's future.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great way to get an overview
REVIEW_BODY: The city gallery is a hidden gem. Truly a great way to see what this city is made of, how it works and where it is going to go. Worth your time!

If you have an hour spare this is an interesting exhibition worth a visit showing how one man's vision for the regeneration of a city came into being. I can think of few cities (if any) that have developed in this way.

REVIEW_TITLE: Explains well how Singapore developed and its future plans
REVIEW_BODY: We did this as part of a food tour and found it fascinating. Shows how Singapore has developed in 50 years from a small country into a powerful trading nation. Worth even a short visit to put the city into perspective

REVIEW_TITLE: A must when looking to understand this city
REVIEW_BODY: Easy to find , cross the street to Maxwell Centre ( great local food and atmosphere). Free entrance for the museum. Lots of information presented very attractively and meaningfully. It is a great learning opportunity about the city, it's problems, their sollutions. It gives hope that clean and sustainable cities are not a dream.

If you are into urban planning, maps, models or how a city can develop, or even if you’re not, the Singapore City Gallery is a very well done space. I found it surprisingly interesting and ended up staying much longer than I expected. There is plenty to read and the models of the city are very impressive and informative.

Entry is free which is a bonus and they do also run guided tours. I’ll certainly recommend this to visitors to Singapore. It’s also directly across the road from the Maxwell Hawker food centre which is handy for pre or post visit food.
I really enjoyed my time here. Its a great gallery to visit and pretty big. I found my visit fun and educational

REVIEW_TITLE: Excellent story of Singapore’s remarkable physical transformation
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a belated review. While not as exciting as the stunning high-tech Urban Planning Exhibition in Shanghai, the free-to-enter Singapore City Gallery is nonetheless of interest to anyone wanting to understand more about the city’s physical transformation over the past 60-odd years, especially to someone like me who, in the 1950s, spent part of their childhood living on the outskirts of the city.

The exhibition, which is on two floors, includes various models, displays and interactive screens that tell the story of Singapore’s development in an engaging way. It also outlines the Urban Redevelopment Authority’s ambitious plans for the future. The gallery, which was a stop during a half-day guided walking tour of the city, is well worth visiting even if you don’t have a professional interest in planning. I visited it twice. It’s just across the road from the Maxwell Food Centre.

At the time of writing this review the gallery is apparently being revamped, although some exhibits are still available for viewing.
This gallery is not so big and free.The second floor which sign in shows how Singapore how grown today with help city planning,enjoyed interactive exhibits

Not all of the floors were open when I visited but this is still an excellent place to visit and the fact that it's free makes it essential. There are loads of interactive exhibitions and information about the city's past, present and future development, as well as two huge models of the city's centre and overall geography. All very interesting, and easily accessible for tourists.

REVIEW_TITLE: Go with Rene of Singapore City Explorers
REVIEW_BODY: I wouldn't have gotten much out of going here alone, but going with Rene of Singapore City Explorers was a fantastic experience. I enjoyed the large model of the city and the board that showed "old" and "new" scenes. The displays were interesting and informative - such as the one on how trash is burned to eliminate trash, create energy and create new land. Just fascinating!!

REVIEW_TITLE: This should be your first stop in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: This museum gives an excellent overview of Singapore’s historic transformation, current land reclamation and future projects such as water independence. This museum also serves to seamlessly integrate every aspect and facet of touring Singapore, such as Chinatown, the Malay enclave, the current project of connecting green spaces and how the geology of the city/state allows for the MTR, tunnels and military secret sites to exist - all under ground!

REVIEW_TITLE: There is urban planning and then there is Singapore...
REVIEW_BODY:
It's a must visit for anybody who wants to understand and marvel at Singapore's urban planning achievements. There is no city in the world that is so forward looking and progressive with its own design trying to strike a balance between functionality, efficiency, affordability and environmental beauty of its living spaces. Truly astonishing when you understand that it was only 50 years ago since Singapore kickstarted its urban development into overdrive.

There is a huge 1:400 scaled model of the city, plus lots of exhibits documenting the different stages in the city development, starting with public housing projects and culminating with its latest efforts around the Marina Bay and its 'Garden City' projects throughout the whole city... Plenty of architectural plans and drawings of the many famous structures in Singapore and around the world designed by Singapore's architectural firms. Lots of models of famous buildings, audiovisual presentations... Future plans... Very impressive and immersive...

Very much recommended for anybody who visits Singapore. One of my favorites!!! And it's FREE to visit;)

See all of my pictures to get a better sense and preview of this superb urban planning museum.

If you're interested in the plans for Singapore's future then this place is well worth a visit. Quite impressive scale model of the central districts on the second floor. Free to enter and not many other visitors. I combined with a lunchtime visit to one of the nearby government offices.

Unlike some other reviewers I believe you will appreciate this excellent exhibition more if you don't go there at the beginning of your stay, but after exploring the city on your own. You will then have seen some of the places shown here and be able to associate with them much more. I continue to be impressed how responsibly this city is being developed and how transparent the URA communicates their master plans.

A very beautiful scale model of the city of Singapore plus a smaller scale model of the entire island definitely worth visiting and free! Plus afterwards or before hand you can stop by Maxwell foodcourt for some authentic Asian cuisine.

Of course, if you find the idea of urban planning terminally dull, you're never going to enjoy this museum. However, if you have an interest in city planning or have found yourself wondering how such a small country functions, this is an excellent, modern museum that can give you a good insight into Singapore's development.

REVIEW_TITLE: In Chinatown? Go see it for an hour.
REVIEW_BODY: A short walk from the Chinatown MRT this is a good place to visit especially if it's raining or extremely hot. It's free and it's interesting. I had never given much thought to town planning but with a country as tiny as Singapore there's clearly no room for error. It was very impressive to see their foresight and how cleverly everything has been, and continues to be, planned and executed. It also gave me an appreciation for the uniqueness of Singapore and made me realize it's not as fabulous as it is by chance. It's most definitely by design.

I decided to visit this Gallery after reading reviews on it. What an amazing experience. The Gallery is a multi sensory journey into the planning of Singapore City. It goes through the past present and future plans of the city and also includes one of the worlds largest architectural models showing a great view of Singapore.
This is worth a visit, takes about 1-1.5 hrs to go though. One hint arrive at 9am opening as by the time I left at 1100 it was packed with school tours.
One of the rare free things to do in Singapore.
Highly recommend!

The City Gallery was an unexpected highlight of my Singapore visit. The massive island and city centre models give a great overview of how this city-state functions and the following displays are truly fascinating. How a tiny country makes do with such a small space is clearly explained for the housing, energy, water, economic, transport, conservation and environmental sectors and is a fascinating story. There are lessons here for visitors from around the world to take home to their own cities.

REVIEW_TITLE: Low Key but Totally Worth it!
REVIEW_BODY:
This is a wonderful museum which displays the urban planning and transformation of Singapore. Best to go early in your trip as it will give you a great perspective of the City and its amazing evolution.
Right next to Maxwell Hawker food center - you can combine the outline with trying the world famous Chicken Rice served there.

REVIEW_TITLE: In awe of the forethought of the planning committees
REVIEW_BODY: This gallery describes how the city was built to what it is today and a glimpse of concepts for the future. I really liked the historical versus current photos and explanations of how it transformed. There are interactive displays as well as the big model of the city. This is a nice place to go for everyone, all ages, and it helps one get oriented with the city. It is especially intriguing if you have any interest in city infrastructure, e.g. architects, engineers, construction, city planners, environmentalists, park goers
For anyone interested in planning, architecture or economic development this is a must. Easy to get to and free!

REVIEW_TITLE: A better view of how Singapore has changed
REVIEW_BODY: This is a great place to see how Singapore has changed over the years. My first trip there was over 40 years ago. The city has changed from a cheap Asian holiday destination to a business hub in the region. It is not the cheap Asian holiday destination that you will find in places like Vietnam but has many advantages over most Asian nations in security and lifestyle.
What a surprise! What a great way to get a feel for the layout of the city, as well as an appreciation for how well Singapore presents itself to tourists.

REVIEW_TITLE: From Showcase In 2013 To Reality In 2016: Our Tampines Hub
REVIEW_BODY: I first saw a model showcasing Our Tampines Hub at the URA Gallery in 2013. It was to be an all-in-one community centre, public service centres, shopping mall, sports stadium and hawker store. I visited the gallery again in November and went across to the real thing in Tampines. In a spate of 3 years, the development came to reality. The sports stadium is still being constructed in its final phase but the rest of Our Tampines Mall is up. This is a suburban community mall for the neighbourhood. Not for temporary visitors to go out of the way to see it unless for curiosity or you have an accommodation nearby. Innovative by developing country standards.

REVIEW_TITLE: Extremely well done and so informative
REVIEW_BODY:
Situated just across the road from Maxwell Hawker Centre, this Gallery was a real eye opener for me. It is extremely well put together and very informative.

I discovered so many facts that I had no idea of prior to my visit. I'm in awe of the foresight and superior skills of those charged with the responsibility of urban planning in Singapore.

Nothing seems to be done 'on the hop', but is planned many years in advance so that everyone has a vision about what they are aiming for. This is a lesson which the planners in my country could take on board instead of having to act at the last minute because they hadn't looked far enough into the future when they released land for building or built roads, etc.

Really enjoyed my visit .Its nothing like you have never seen before but Interesting part that many companies have provided information about their buildings which has facilitated the construction of the models. and gives overview how singapore transformed from a village
Different scale models give good perspective of both City and island and BC future plans. You realise how much of downtown is on reclaimed land.

An airconditioned interesting overview of Singapore - to get an idea and scale of this teeny nation. Great multimedia displays too. Lots of school tour groups during the week, although the children are extremely well behaved. An easy walk from Chinatown.

This place is so great for people who want to know more about the country and its urban planning development. I'm a urban planning nerd so the URA itself is a must-go for me. But this place offers so many interesting things for visitors to see that I'm sure even people who had no interest in urban planning would like here.

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice Exhibit to Understand How the City is Setup
REVIEW_BODY: Just a few steps away from Maxwell Food Center near Chinatown. It's a good place to start (or end) a trip to Singapore, as it gives a lot of insight on how the city was built. There is a small map on the ground floor, but the main gallery is on the 2nd floor. Exhibits are divided into sections focusing on different aspects of urban planning---conservation efforts, nature and parks, etc. Near the giant map is a small area where you can sit and watch short videos about the neighborhoods of Singapore. Quite happy that I visited this museum.

REVIEW_TITLE: a must to understand the country
REVIEW_BODY:
very very interesting and well arranged exhibition on the urban development and history of the city state
pride for the national achievement is definitely the base of all the exhibition, and I guess that the final goal is to strengthen the national pride of the Singaporeans (lots of school classes visiting while I was there)
all is extremely professional, appealing and informative.
there is clearly some propaganda in it, but extremely well presented, and the advertised item is so outstanding that some self complacency is acceptable
overall a vist is worthwhile and a must to understand Singapore

REVIEW_TITLE: Outstanding Site for Strategists and Planners
REVIEW_BODY: This gallery and museum connected to city services for land use had excellent exhibits about Singapore's development history and plans for the future. If you've ever wanted to know how the city-nation makes its decisions and implements them (given its slightly over 50 years as an independent nation) this is the place for you.

REVIEW_TITLE: past present and future of Singapore well explained
REVIEW_BODY: My Profession, love for cities and its developments and My Urban Designer friend dragged me to this place. This place Showcase the Singapore thoroughly and how this place has grown to what it is today. Along with this it takes you back to past and shows strategies of the development. Its free for all and explains what it takes to be good city.

This placeis pretty good - give you an insight into the planning and development of Singapore as well as a scaled model of the country with future structures in place. A visit here can take several hours depending how involved you want to get.

Was my very first stop in this city and a good idea at that. A free tour through the times of Singapore. It really makes you appreciate where they have come from to where they are now. A definite first stop on any travellers itinerary as it puts everything into perspective before you begin exploring the wonders that Singapore has to offer.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting and nice city model+good presentation
REVIEW_BODY: It was a great city gallery to represent the story of the Singapore country, map and history of the place. I like it is a good mix to use data technology to display and make it easy to understand for visitors. I am happy to visit and see the good stuffs and more information of Singapore country.

REVIEW_TITLE: A fountain of information about the city
REVIEW_BODY: I really enjoyed my visit here. The displays show a deep respect for both the city and it's people. The scale models of the island and the inner city are fabulous. Interesting to note that many companies have provided information about their buildings which has facilitated the construction of the models. Also interesting is the drawings - easily accessible to the public - of past and future developments to the city.

The gallery is close to the Maxwell food court and after having some great hawker stand food, I decided to pay the gallery a visit. The exhibits are great and you learn a lot how Singapore transformed from a village into a super modern cosmopolitan city.

I started my trip to Singapore here. It really added value to the remainder of the trip as I had the history and context of the city in my mind.

Don't be fooled thinking this is for city planners and architecture buffs. Anyone with a general interest in cities will enjoy this. It is also free.

Top tip: right next door Maxwell hawker centre has great food including chicken rice. Time your visit so you can nip in for lunch.

First time visit Singapore, many people recommend me to come here. This free museum is located not far from China Town. The interpretation is telling the history of Singapore are. Unbelievable small area can be double price on living expense now.

This museum tell us, nothing to make it happen , if human is stronger enough.
It's free learning centre which visitor should go.

REVIEW_TITLE: Free "museum", it's really a contemporary exhibition about Singapore's urban planning
REVIEW_BODY: From all over the world Singapore is visited by city planners, because this city does it so well and thinks 30 years ahead. Try to pick up one of the free guided tours.

This tells us the story about Singapore, nice history and historical pictures. Lot of interesting buildings, architecture and models of buildings. Free entrance, close to Maxwell Food Center, which is also worth a visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: An amazing insight into Singapore’s history, growth and development
REVIEW_BODY: Located on Maxwell Road, near Chinatown and the Maxwell Food Centre. Entry to the Gallery is free and it’s open Monday to Saturday from 9am to 5pm. This 3 storey visitor gallery showcases Singapore’s physical transformation in the last 50 years. Whilst the main feature is the 11 metre by 10 metre architectural model of Central Singapore, which is amazingly detailed & intricate, the audiovisual and interactive exhibits on the third floor highlight the city's physical transformation past, present and future. A must for people interested in architecture and town planning or if you want to learn more about how the city was planned and developed over the years as well as it’s plans for the future.
I thought it was an art gallery when I went in but it turned out to be a review of the city's history and future from a town planning perspective. A little dry but very interesting nonetheless...
Knowledgeable experience, they have a guided tour every 1 hour or so and get to know a lot of things about city future developments.

REVIEW_TITLE: Start your visit of Singapore here!
REVIEW_BODY: Visited the City Gallery as a part of the Food Tour of Singapore, and so glad we did! What a fascinating, inspiring and IMPRESSIVE city! So much urban planning, foresight for the future and the environment, and such an interesting history. Please close attention to the description of the "Samsui women" - and then watch for their statues around the country. What courageous women to keep Singapore building UP after WWII!
Best to visit as a group. The rather large gallery showcases the country's transformation over the years, and provides a fascinating introduction to urban planning in Singapore.

From historical maps to modern master plans, this gallery tells the story of 200 years of development. Coupled with interactive features and 3D models, the whole tour is highly engaging and informative.
A brilliant assortment of designs that give a glimpse of the past, present, and future of Singapore cityscap
It best showcases the Singapore's development story over the years. Place has models that encompasses city architectural plans & landmarks

This is an exhibition that show the development of Singapore. It is a working demonstration with some very informative informative interactively displayed. It is in English with much information provided and ideas developed. Well worth your time to visit this display.

This is the place I recommend every visitor to go to . It shows how the city evolved since it was first discovered. There are good activities showing the structure and planning . It is just a pity that museum has been under renovation for so long and we cannot access the main interactive rooms .

REVIEW_TITLE: A place to visit for Past - Present - Future of Singapore City
REVIEW_BODY:
This one place tourist attraction place must visit to complete and compliments, if one has a short visit to the City State. It is design and give a broad landscape of this tiny red dot island from the 50's historical and heritage background to present infra-structure of the eco-modern urban city.
Congras to URA City Planner Team

REVIEW_TITLE: 3D models that explain the city development
REVIEW_BODY: WOW I love this place. I’m glad I went in my first day in Singapore as it helped me understand the deliberate planning actions that have made this city the way it is.
Good place to learn about past and future, urban planning of Singapore. I can spend hours looking at the diorama. More interesting for residents.

REVIEW_TITLE: A Must do to Understand the Development of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: This is a great display showing the development of Singapore. Do it with a guide for best understanding of how Singapore came to be as it is today.

REVIEW_TITLE: A snapshot of Singapore's town planning and future development, in one place
REVIEW_BODY:
The city gallery is not a tourist attraction but a government department's (Urban Redevelopment Authority) office which has a gallery on the first and second level.

If you like town planning, history, architecture and design, then this is the place for you. The displays provide a quick overview of the city's development from the 1960s to now and beyond.

On the ground floor there is a miniature model of Singapore, but sometimes there may be other themed display or exhibition at the same place.

On the second level of the gallery is a larger scale model of central Singapore which is very interesting as they have more details. There are also some interactive displays.

This is my Favourite place to bring overseas guests and visitors. No booking or prior appointment is required. Just walk in and it's free.
Recommended for all visitors as well as people living here in Singapore. Learn about the urban infrastructure of Singapore and the plans for future development of the city.

Presented in a way that should appeal to everyone from a family with kids escaping the heat for an hour to an urban planning enthusiast like myself. Absolutely worth it. Singapore is an incredible city and you really get a vision of that with these excellent exhibits.

We went as part of our college trip to URA centre. A must visit place if you want to know more about Singapore and how it has transformed quickly over the years to what it is today. The staff who explained these to us were very knowledgeable and addressed all our doubts. They are experts when it comes to Singapore's history. Very informative session which would make you realize how such a small country was able to create a large impact on the world.

If you are interested in learning about the development of this amazing city, this is the place to visit. It is a surprisingly well presented layout of Singapore's development into this modern bustling metropolis. The scale models are fabulous and forces one to identify where one is staying in the city and the surrounding area. It is a quiet oasis that is also free in a city that rivals Scandinavian countries in being expensive.

REVIEW_TITLE: Complerte City Model you can walk around
REVIEW_BODY: We stumbled on this exhibit by accident and were amazed. It is free to the public and the many halls, galleries, and pictures give a detailed history of the transformation of Singapore from a pre-WWII fishing village to a vibrant, modern country and the planning and work that has gone into the transformation.

I went to Singapore with my friend, who is an urban planning student, and she insisted to come here. It was really a worth visit. The gallery was well-maintained. We can explore Singapore in the past, now, and the future plan. They had a good display, and it was free!

I love this kind of gallery in any city and the URA has done a really good job here. It is really informative for both residents and visitors alike. If you are into this kind of thing you can easily spend 2 hours here. And it's free, so that's an added bonus!
Singapore urbanism is unique and this place explains you perfectly how and why Singapore is Singapore. Worth a short visit

Worth visiting the city gallery to see a lot of models of plans for Singapore for the next 10years. Also what Singapore has looked like. We even had a chance to go on a 3D simulator to walk up and down a street in Singapore to explore wearing a headset and computer goggles. It was amazing! A lot of great photos to be taken too.

Came back here for another visit recently. The big model map of Singapore is still there, but it's a little tricky to see what the future development plans are - this is by no means obvious. Perhaps next time I need to try for one of the guided tours which may explain it more clearly.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to start a journey
REVIEW_BODY: It's a great place to start your journey in Singapore. You will not only see the history but also the future of this city. All those great documentaries and scale model of the city skyscrapers. Really love this place.

REVIEW_TITLE: Good to see to know about Singapore!
REVIEW_BODY: This place makes us to know how singapore had skylines, modern buildings and what the future plans of singapore! Its really amazing to know about all. Must Go!

REVIEW_TITLE: first thing to see in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: this gallery allows visitors to realise the metamorphosis of the city, from the fishers village to the present day's city. obviously you can't miss the city centre model at the end.

REVIEW_TITLE: The perfect place to get insights of how Singapore transformed from marshes to city in a garden!
REVIEW_BODY:
The Singapore City Gallery is an exhibition within the building of the Urban Redevelopment Authority of Singapore.

Conveniently situated in the town area of Singapore (i.e. Tanjong Pagar and Chinatown), this exhibition provides visitors with enriching insights about some urban redevelopment initiatives undertaken by the authority that propelled Singapore to clinch the top honour as one of the most liveable cities in the world.

Find out how limited natural resources such as land and water were maximised to accomodate to the plan of increasing Singapore's population to ensure that it remains competitive as an accomplished nation in the global arena.

Well worth the visit if you would like to understand how Singapore has developed over the years. You may also be pleased to know that admission is free of charge!

We are amazed with this free gallery. Consists of three levels, 1st level is for exhibition, 2nd level and 3rd level show and tell about singapore history, development, and future plan. Very educating and informative. The great thing is they provide it free for public.
How to get there: Alight at Tanjong Pagar MRT station, exit to Maxwell Road, walk along the red dot building and cross the street, you will see the URA building(singapore city gallery)
